name: Injera
description: A staple of Ethiopian cuisine, injera is a sourdough-risen flatbread with a unique, slightly spongy texture. Traditionally made from teff flour, it is used as a plate and utensil to scoop up stews and salads.
steps: Mix teff flour with water in a bowl until smooth, then cover and let ferment for 1-3 days.
After fermentation, stir the batter well and add salt.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat.
Pour a ladleful of batter into the pan and quickly swirl to spread in a thin layer.
Cover and cook for a few minutes until holes form on the surface and edges lift from the pan.
Remove injera and let cool on a clean cloth. Repeat with remaining batter.
tips: The batter should be thin and smooth to ensure proper fermentation.
Do not flip injera when cooking; it cooks through from one side.
Use a lid while cooking to help steam and fully cook the top surface.
